>>2549455
I work for a company that does commercial and industrial low voltage wiring. Ethernet, industrial automation, security cameras, door controllers, VOIP phones, etc. We do not do residential stuff.

I did a job for an industrial client where we wired a new manufacturing facility from the ground up. Networking, video security system, and a few door controllers. They requested that each type of network use different color cables. Okay, weird, but sure. We ordered cables in several different colors. Generally we only have blue and gray. They wanted a color for computers, phones, security, doors, and a few more for the different types of machines they were operating. We had to special order cable and it cost a bit more. They had me run hundred of drops as well as setup a rack and patch panel for them. This project took weeks and thousands of feet of cable. We gave them cost estimates every step of the way and finished on time and under budget.

When it came time to sign off of it they challenged EVERYTHING on the invoice, line by line. We told them up front that cable in other colors would cost a bit extra because no one locally carried it and we'd have to order some. They sign off on it. We billed them for that exact amount and they challenged it. They said 'We were billed less for these blue and gray cables. Why can't we get that rate for everything?' 'Because those cables cost us less.' 'Why was some many feet of cable used?' 'Why were so many wall jacks used?' 'Can you lower the price on these?' Every fucking thing was like that. We ended up sending them to collections. One of the owners actually showed to our company Christmas party to badger our project manager for a lower price. I remember them having a screaming match in front of the office where the guy kept yelling 'What do we have to do to get this to go away??' and our manager just saying over and over again 'pay the bill, pay the bill, pay the bill'.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2561468
Long story short, they got caught out by COVID-19. They started the project right as everyone was going into lockdown and the business was running well into the red when the bill came. They did recover, and even paid the bill, but this little tantrum (plus other bullshit the pulled at the same time) did not go over well with the locals. You live in a small town and shit like that gets around.

Another fun story. We setup a law office. New workstations, a server with a few VMs, firewall, wiring, phones, migration of the old data, some P2V of the older servers, a backup system, the works. We sent the invoice and the guy said 'I won't be paying it'. No excuses either. Just 'Nah, not paying it. What are you gonna do? Sue me?' The absolute balls on that guy. We didn't bother sending him to collections. We waited about 4 month and, when he still refused to pay, we remoted into his network and encrypted everything. Not a crypto virus or shit like that. Total drive encryption for the computers and revoking of the licneses for the firewall, phones and backup system. They rolled up on Monday and everything went to a boot screen with a password. No phones, no internet, no backups, nothing. Long story short he sued us but didn't have a leg to stand on. We countersued and he settled, as his business was going down the shitter without access to most of his company data.

Sounds great, stick it to the asshole and all that but the aggravation of shit like that. My boss drives a Porsche but he also has an ulcer and is prematurely gray. No thanks. I make enough money that I can buy all the toys I want and not have to deal with these fuckheads.

1/2. What pre-made objects would make a good base for a beetleweight (3lb) shell spinner? It's a hard design to get right, especially on a budget, but I have always wanted to make one so here we are.
I fooled around with a wedge and bare bones vert. spinner in some regional beetleweight and antweight (1lb)combat "robot" competitions in the mid 00s, and have some experience with rc plane construction, and so have most of the tools I need already.
What I cannot figure out is the shell. CNC or waterjet would put me over budget, so I am left with modifying and existing object.
The finished shell should be 55 to 70% of the total robot weight, being as rigid as possible, while at the same time very tough.
The ideal shell for a beetleweight would probably have waterjet cut grade 5 titanium body with s7 tool steel teeth, to give you an ideal.
I would feel better about going with aluminum on a 1lb bot, 3lb spinners have gotten nasty with more builders using brushless motors. However, I am not totally against it, maybe some 7 series AL with full height vertical steel teeth would be ok.
That leaves steel, which for the weight will be less rigid than the AL, or ti, but more affordable and less prone to steel weapons gouging it. The rigidity would be improved with the addition of a steel ring fastened/welded to the bottom. So far I've thought of:
-A small high end pan or wok (this worked for blendo, but I am struggling to find one both small and robust enough)
-the dome "bell" portion of an older style school/emergency bell(not a lot of info on the material and thickness of these however)
-a large di. section of seamless AL or steel pipe, with a circular plate fastened to the top
-the domed top portion of an oxygen/other gas cylinder/beefy fire extinguisher base
-some sort of wheel or hub, not sure what sort, maybe go-cart?
-a very large hole saw bit (hard to find over 6" and the thick top and thin sides are not ideal)
-some sort of high end pipe cap I don't know about

Sorry to keep you waiting

NEC 200.7(C) Circuits of 50 Volts or More
The use of insulation that is white or gray or that has three continuous white or gray stripes for other than a grounded conductor for circuits of 50 volts or more shall be permitted only as in (1) and (2).
If part of a cable assembly that has the insulation permanently reidentified to indicate its use as an ungrounded conductor by marking tape, painting, or other effective means at its termination and at each location where the conductor is visible and accessible. Identification shall encircle the insulation and shall be a color other than white, gray, or green.

While it does not specify red, the most common colors for hot wires in a residential load center are red and black and there is already a black wire.

>NO WHERE IN THE NEC DOES IT SPECIFIY THAT THE COLOR RED BE USED ON A CURRENT CARRYING CONDUCTOR
It is true that very few colors are specified in the code book. However, choosing a color other than red in that specific application can lead to being gently guided to 90.4 in the code book by the inspector. You'll find out about that once you finish studying the code book just to pass the test. It's a real world thing, not a sneaky code theory question.
Sometimes the AHJ wants purple to be the second phase for a 277/480 system because orange is also a high leg. If you decide to pick blue instead because there is "nothing in the codebook", the AHJ will happily remind you that you, while being technically right, are also wrong. Wrong enough to fail the inspection. Because the authority having jurisdiction for enforcement of theCodehas the responsibility for making interpretations of the rules, for deciding on the approval ofequipment and materials. And how would you, as an electrician, not know to use red.

>>2543617
>I think you only recently introduced RCD's despite them being 20 years old and even then they're on individual points rather than the circuit
this is flat out incorrect, but over here we just call them GFCI rather than RCD.
>solid core ----- they're more prone to breaking,
This isn't true. For one thing, it's a lot easier to break or accidentally nick/cut a strand in a stranded cable during stripping or terminating, which reduced its effective diameter and makes it less than the proper size. Also, IDK how much work hardening you expect to happen with solid core wires in a residential or light commercial setting, but it's simply a non-issue.

Your complaints are simply without merit and are entirely inane and without any relevance. These are non issues, and if you want to complain about USA wiring practices, you should at least pick a topic that is actually worth complaining about like the requirements for buggy AFCI protection, the buggy and insecure "smart" meters, the best effort/rule-of-thumb grounding electrode system rules, etc etc etc.

At the end of the day, the real issue is not hypothetical superiority of one path vs another. The question is: what are the failure rates or safety/damage incidence rates in this system vs another.

a gfci (american term for RCD) outlet can be installed in a way that protects the entire circuit it's installed on just like a gfci/rcd breaker. we use gfci outlets in places where a ground fault is more common (around water sources in homes) so you don't have to go to the breaker box to reset it, and often limit them to just the outlet where ground fault is common to avoid the annoyance of an entire circuit going down from a ground fault at the one outlet
I agree that gfci/rcd breakers are a generally more robust and overall safer solution but we also very commonly use gfci breakers as well

>>2550142
>There should be three conducters and a ground - red and black for the 220, white to the neutral, copper to ground.
You only need a neutral if there is unbalanced current. Any pure 240 VAC device only needs two hots and ground.
>that neutral and ground are the same fucking thing
They are not. Neutrals (grounded conductors) are for unbalanced current return. Grounds (grounding conductors) are for safety. That's why you do not bond neutrals and grounds in subpanels because you could inadvertently energize ground (earth, grounding conductor) in the rest of the system.

>>2551344
Neutral/ground are the same thing for the linemen. Your drop is being held up in the air by your neutral/ground tap to the transformer. The same bare wire that holds your drop up is connected to the center tap, then some grounded mounting hardware, then goes over to your house where it grounds again on your weatherhead.

The ground all up and down the pole is grounded with either a series of ground rods or a coil of wire the pole sits on. Not every pole needs one, it can get its ground from the other poles it's connected to.

Euro anon wants a separate neutral wire to the transformer. Which won't do anything, your 120v appliances will still get 240v through them when the neutral breaks. You'll call the power company and probably get out to avoid the fire.

>>2551413
You don't understand what "ground" is, and what it's for, obviously. And, planes and cars are grounded at certain times, like fueling - the gas pump hose you use is a ground, so no sparks will happen while fueling - planes do the same. A lot of trucks and forklifts have grounding straps on the floor/road, as well.
When a plane is in the air, it's neutral cicruits in the plane's wiring is all it needs, but once on the ground, to reduce spark danger, they're grounded to bring the potential of the plane to the same as the ground.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_(electricity)#:~:text=In%20electricity%20supply%20systems%2C%20an,compatibility%20of%20the%20power%20supply.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
to all the retards who dont know yank electric, listen up. a the equipment grounding conductors and neutrals (grounded conductors) are bonded at the first means of disconnect because in our electrical system, ground fault currents return to the utility on the neutral (grounded conductor). the equipment grounding conductors have nothing to do with bonding or systems grounding. they are 100% necessary as a safety so if there is a ground fault, it has a low resistance path to source which causes a massive current to rush through the breaker, causing it to trip very quickly.
I would highly recommend watching Mike Holt's video on grounding and bonding. it's on youtube, and it's solid gold

>>2563138
A transit level is pretty much exactly what you're describing. However they are usually only good for a few hundred feet at most, at a mile away you're not going to have the resolution to discern 30", especially when factoring in curvature of earth, and light or haze interference over the distance. A good transit level has an accuracy of maybe 1/8" at 100'. So for 1 mile, that's an accuracy of 7 or 8 inches, but probably more since it may not be a linear degradation of accuracy. You may be able to do better with electronic laser type instrumentation but then you're getting into the really expensive stuff.

Yes. If you have a viewpoint that is tangent with the surface of the earth (meaning it is "level" at that point), then what that viewpoint intersects at 1 mile away is around 66' higher in elevation from the surface than the viewpoint is. And that's not even accounting for any rises and dips in the terrain. All of this needs to be taken into account when performing long distance surveying.

So to get an accurate reading of an object's height at 1 mile, you would need to tilt your viewpoint down from level by 0.725 degrees to make the base reference the same at both ends.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2563385
>0.725 degrees is a very small angle
43 arcminutes? That's a positively massive angle in surveying terms. Curvature of the Earth is only about 35 arcseconds per mile. Most equipment nowadays has accuracy of 5 arcseconds or better (usually 3" or 1").
Also, the problem is someone misplaced his decimal when he drew the circle and made it only about 40 miles in radius instead of almost 4000 miles.
Still, you're going to have issues seeing the target at that distance (a mile). Just a bit of heat distortion along the ground will wreck your vision, to say nothing of what vibrations to the instrument itself would do.
Leica/Hexagon, Trimble/Spectra, and Topcon are the main survey gear manufacturers that I know of; you may be able to find a dealer near you with used or rentals. Careful about buying from fleabay -- no guarantee when anything from there was last calibrated or even still works, and almost anything on there will be hard to get parts for.

So the alarm switch on this digital clock is clearly designed to fail after a few hundred cycles, it's basically a couple pads on the PCB with a piece of metal on the bottom of a plastic slide switch. The copper had completely worn through making the switch inoperable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2563606
>You're just poisoning yourself and the environment for nothing.

Metallic lead (as opposed to water soluble lead compounds) is perfectly safe so long as you take reasonable precautions. Lead free solder is why electronics don't last as long as they used to, tin whiskers + fine pitch electronics (which definitely includes today's SMT stuff) is a bad combination. So you use less lead but also end up with more stuff going to landfills. Also the more aggressive synthetic fluxes used with lead free solder are more toxic than rosin which is literally just tree sap.

IC prices have literally doubled, in some cases even tripled, in recent years.

As for the smaller Fatshark style goggles, the main cost there is the microdisplays - they’re a very low volume, niche component so are always going to be expensive. The bigger, clunkier box style goggles use generic 4” - 7” LCD panels which are dirt cheap because they’re such high volume parts used by so many different products.

My walksnail vrx module review:
>kind of disappointing as my first digital experience
>quality is certainly better than analog, but not by a *lot*. My analog camera (caddx ratel) seems to have better colours and dynamic range and better low light sensitivity.
>people say it has better penetration... but this comes at a cost. Instead of analog breakup you get pixellation like youtube at 240p and lag. Even with no obstructions, the picture often feels a little blurry and not crisp HD.
>for mild obstructions such as a few branches, penetration is probably superior to analog. But for medium to heavy obstructions, such as flying around a concrete barn, the lag can get so bad it's hard to fly. The analog breakup is also terrible in this location but I still get enough up to date information to not crash, whereas the walksnail picture can feel like it's lagging by a whole second.
Think I will try HDzero in a while when there are more range of vtx available.

posts.com: I have been working for a contractor who does a little of everything. Carpentry, brick, stone, painting, drywall, etc. It’s awesome and I love it. Now I am thinking I eventually want to do an actual apprenticeship for something like electrical, plumbing, or carpentry. Lately though, I have been feeling like such a fucking retard. I am such a slow learner and it feels like I am wayyy behind where I technically should be. I don’t know if it is because my mom just never taught me anything, my adhd, me always being so focused on weightlifting, boxing, or just keeping my head above water for school. Having never really done anything beyond simple repairs or troubleshooting stuff, my handy-ness is bleak. My boss gets pretty pissed at me sometimes. Like when I take too long screwing shit so I don’t strip it, too long straightening up the drill (had no idea it could suck me in like that), or when I wasnt’t cutting brick straight enough. He handed me a bolt to hammer into a beam and turns out it wasn’t quite long enough, so it got only a nut with no washer or lock washer. He said that usually given two options, I pick the wrong one. But he does compliment how I am very strong and have an eye for detail. With most of the stuff I do great it is just some of this tool oriented stuff I am falling short on. Are there books or things I can do to learn the lingo, do’s and don’ts, and proper ways to use tools so that I am not as stupid as I am now. posts.name: Anonymous

>>2559728
It takes time to get really good at any particular skill area. It's not just knowing how to do it, but spending lots of hours doing it to build up dexterity and muscle memory until you become a real pro.

There are lots of people who can do plumbing, electrical, carpentry, masonry, finish carpentry, and more. But there are extremely few people who are masters at all of them at the same time.
Also, being the fastest at everything doesn't necessarily mean that you're doing the best quality work or doing things the safest way

Anon. Everyone sucks in the beginning of any learning process. What matters is attitude and a willingness to keep trying until you understand.

You clearly have these things. Keep applying them and the rest will follow. Keep your eyes and ears open and your mouth shut - learn from experienced Men. Learn their tricks. Practice the skills you most need. And remember - first you get Good, then you get Fast.

Don’t worry about fucking up. Failure comes to every man sooner or later. What matters is how you respond to it. Do you learn from it? Adapt and come back better? Or do you let it beat you down?

I think you know the answer. You sound like a good lad with a lot of potential. Work smart, look after your health, and be a sponge for useful knowledge.

>Are there books or things I can do to learn the lingo, do’s and don’ts, and proper ways to use tools so that I am not as stupid as I am now
Practice is pretty much the only way to get good at it, even if you were to study this shit. You could read 1000 books about how to use a hammer, you'll still smash your fingers the first time you use it. Just like boxing, a lot of it is muscle memory, which you can only get by doing that particular thing for long enough.
But if you want super detailed info on how to do certain things, then go to the source: ask your boss or your coworkers about how they learned it. You're much more likely to find out from them than by asking here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2554210
Have a decent workshop, plenty of tools and know how to use them. That way natural disasters are easy to respond to and you can quickly repair your property.

Be creative and question customs many of which are lazy defaults. How many people do you know who when they repair or renovate plumbing strategically add spigots and fittings for garden hose? I can bypass any section of my plumbing almost as quick as I can drag the hose and that's insanely handy. I buy replacement well pumps opportunistically in advance saving stoopid money then skid mount them with important fittings already mounted. I can connect those to either of my wells as desired. I keep a Bosworth Guzzler hand pump so I'll never have to manually prime again.

Prepping buys time thus choice. Stored water buys time to sort out water replenishment.

With water sorted tackle food. That's been done to death making it silly ITT because no one should need spoonfeeding for basic shit.

Transportation vehicles should be extremely common with a very large aftermarket and salvage yard presence. Idiots buy Larp Rovers without solving the parts and mechanic problems first. I buy redundant old pickup trucks (Ford and GM because brandfaggotry is silly) I can personally troubleshoot and repair axle-to-axle.

If drainage matters solve that shit. Ditches ain't hard to manually dig over time but flooding is bad. Ensure your vehicle parking spot is easy to egress and never ever buy land in a flood zone.

Why would you go with a 100W 12V inverter - Why not just use a DC to DC converter to go from 12V to 5V @ .5 A for the cellphone charger?

That way you do not lose 20/30% for the inverter and another 10% for the chargers to convert the AC back into DC.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2555738
box? are you looking for a tool box? that doesn't matter so much as the quality of the tools, and you can't beat japanese, see the japanese "engineer" brand tools. snap-on is about equal. they don't overlap in every area, and engineer focuses more on hand tools.
Old tools are great too, they don't make 'em like they used to but for SHTF? Depends on the scenario; surviving in the wilderness? escaping a city? just staying in your home but with no outside help anymore?
I'll tell you the tools I would take with me, from an "everything is gone and I have to move" perspective. I go wild camping a lot and urbexing overnight (aka being homeless in a city temporarily) there's one tool I always want with me;
an axe. it can be both a hammer and cutting tool, makes your firewood, makes your shelter, deters attackers. small 2lb/1kg hatchet is best.
Optional extras:
-those small pocket bolt cutters.
-nibblers (great for sheet metal, snips are good but i prefer nibblers. made a wood burning stove recently from random scrap metal me and my gang of raiders found, pic related, using only snips, a drill, some fireplace cement (can substitute clay/mud) and some wood screws, axe as a hammer was helpful too)
-folding saw (you can get the cheap ones from garden centres)
-pliers and/or adjustable water pump wrench.
-engineer brand side cutters (good for all kinds of things, including trimming nails and minor surgery)
-swiss army knife (explorer) that's the one with the magnifying glass and screwdriver. covers so many bases; can opener, tweezers, blade, even a secret wire stripper function.
Now if you want to get really fancy;
-one good No.2 Phillips screwdriver.
-one good large slotted driver.
-one slotted electricians screwdriver.
(i recommend wera brand screwdrivers)
-set of allen keys
-wood chisel
-brick hammer
-high quality military folding shovel
your pack now weighs about 4kg more. Unless relly necessary, you will probably end up reducing it to swiss army knife and axe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fuel oil (red diesel) can be stored for a very long time
and used to heat your home or run a generator

A fireplace is always good to have. Especially one you can use for cooking.

Never return home with an empty gas tank. Keep it at least half filled at all times.
Keep an emergency jerry can at home. Dont forget to use that fuel and replace it with new fuel. Fuel can spoil.

Buy drinking water. Keep it sealed and store it properly.
Buy canned food. Ready to eat meals and some ingredients.
Also store dry food like rice.

Get paper plates, cups etc. Cleaning the dishes when water is scarce is a real pain.
Use plastic cups for drinking water.

>>2556902
You've clearly not been through any or many disasters.

Have a known good supply of clean water you control which means maintain your well if so equipped including backup pump and spare parts or have clean storage like food grade poly barrels you leave empty until warning of disaster (keep full if earthquake country). Rainwater is not a reliable resource but if in a rainy area and a homeowner you can and I do leave rain barrels beneath the edges of building roofs. Mine are for convenient washing after working outdoors and to wet the area where I weld and cut prior to hot work, but they do fine for flushing the shitter and general washing.

Weapons fantasy prep is mostly for retarded larpdreaming incompetents beyond the basic rifle/shotgun/pistol everyone should own anyway. Never plan for your dreams because dreams are stupid. Plan based on reality.

Be extremely handy and able to work on everything you own that matters. That includes at least one simple, common vehicle.

You don't need electricity or entertainment. Reserve food shouls be canned or otherwise stored not to need cold storage. Run genset long enough to use up what you have then shut it down to reserve it for important tasks. Solar battery chargers are enough to run toys, charge LED headlamps (holding a flashlight wastes a hand when wrenching or anything else) etc. LED headlamps remove any need to run lights in your residence. Have small inverters and know how to power and charge what matters. Portable cell towers are easily deployed after major disasters so you want at least one good backup phone. A CB radio or two is useful. Learn why.

This guy's on the right track.
There's not going to be some "SHTF" scenario where the country turns into a giant battle royale. It will be a slow decline, where little by little the standard of living will decrease, and economic security becomes harder to come by.
For some examples, look at what happened in Russia after the Soviet Union dissolved. That was as close as possbile to the "SHTF" the mad max preppers dream of, it was basically the end of the world for many people, and yet life still went on.

What you should be doing is adopting habits that lower your dependency on the immediate economic situation. Growing your own food means that you don't have to worry about going hungry. Learning to repair stuff means that you don't have to go without, and maybe you can repair other people's things in exchange for their talents, like sewing.
Basically the opposite strategy to cowering in your bunker with 2 years of canned beans and 12 guns, shooting anyone who comes near.

In a SHTF scenario, all the money you have in the bank disappears, stock market goes completely dead, companies no longer functions if they even exist. In order for your investments to actually benefit you, you need to turn them into cash and goods BEFORE shit hits the fan.

No, you're not going to be able to use your phone for internet because the cell infrastructure has been rendered non-functional because the towers need power to work.

No, you aren't going to survive the week let alone long enough for the government to regain it's footing since you decided to put all your assets out of physical reach and your fridge only has a few days worth of food and the water no longer works.

No, you can't just drive away since every major road would be packed with cars, crashed or otherwise, and since you thought you could purchase everything when the time came you don't have any long term survival plans or supplies.

And lastly, Katrina was essentially a large, but localized, disaster since no governments or countries were rendered powerless or completely isolated. And people were able to be evacuated. and supplies were able to get in
Evacuations are impossible during an SHTF scenario because their is no where else safe to
run and no help coming.

Prepping is a bet

>>2558379
I'm glad someone mentioned medical supplies. They're cheap when there's no emergency so its a good first step to prepping. Do not buy "medical kits" in the store, they're overpriced garbage and most don't come with useful medical supplies save for a few gauze pads. Assemble your own TRAUMA kit according to your needs. You want things in it to solve problems that require IMMEDIATE medical attention. Some good things to have in it are:

1. Gauze. Lots of Gauze. Various sizes. Do not just get large pads thinking you can cut them to size, cutting gauze is bad for wound healing. ABD tauma pads too.
2. Iodine. It does not expire. Do not use alcohol. Do not use hydrogen peroxide
3. Saline and an insturment to flush wounds with.
4. Tweezers/instruments/flashlight/especially scissors for cutting open clothes to access wounds easier.
5. Steri-strips (butterfly bandages). It really pisses me off how many med kits do not come with these when they really should. These are the best thing to seal up open cut wounds that need to be stitched.
6. Self-adhesive bandage wraps, will come in handy if you can't use a hand.
7. Large triangular bandage for sling
8. Tourniquet. Pray you'll never use it, but having it can be life over death.
9. Eyewash.
10. Your needed emergency meds (Nitroglycerin/epishots)
11. Lighter for sterilizing tools/knives/needles and potential cauterizing.
12. Gloves/safeties/washing kit

Don't get stupid little band aids. Band aids are bullshit, knuckle bandages/square/culture friendly, what the fuck ever they're garbage. You can get stitching stuff, but only use them if you know what the fuck you're doing. It's painful unless you can manage to get anesthetic and needles and you will probably fuck it up worse. Steri-strips are more user friendly and should hold you off until you can get proper treatment.

Usually you preheat either the air or fuel. Preheated air is preferred due to safety (assuming it isn't oil as a fuel which loves preheating) and simplicity. Preheating the mixture is usually hard due to the short path.

posts.com:
>>2555649
copper demand went up because of electronics, now it's rises again with "green tech" like solar panels, grid batteries and electric cars

at the same time, ore grade steadily decreases over time
copper content in ore these days is around 1%, usually less
we aren't really going to run out, but it lower grade = more expensive to process
you need to dig up more rock - if the copper in ore decreases from 1% to 0.5%, you need to increase the amount of ore mined by 100% - you double the costs, but the production stays the same

aluminum meanwhile is several orders of magnitude more abundant, the ores are typically around 50% Aluminum, so the cost is based almost purely on the price of electricity needed to convert it to metal
And because you can turn electrolysis on and off, you can work with daytime peaks somewhat and use only cheap electricity
It's not ideal from the process engineering perspective, but if your main ingredient comes for free at certain times of the day, you might consider getting into throttleable production.

>tl;dr: more renewables = copper will keep getting even more expensive and aluminum will keep getting cheaper

posts.com:
I work in a power plant and virtually all the thick wires are aluminum. The "problem" as I know it is dealing with greater thermal expansion/contraction at connections which works terminations loose over time. This is done by doing away with crimps, solder, or screw/clamp terminations. All the connections I see are wire-wire welds or wire-hoop welds.

As other anon mentioned- HV transmission lines are almost universally an aluminum conductor wrapped around steel core (for strength).

Shit works, there's decades of known best-practices for making it work, one just has to follow the instructions. If one can't follow instructions then there's always copper with its associated idiot tax.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2556580
Wouldn't copper-plated aluminum actually be alright?
The biggest issue with Al is that the surface oxidizes faster than you can work it so joining wires is a much bigger fuck around. Cu will protect the Al from oxidation so you can use traditional splicing methods, while the Al carries the majority of the current.
Of course, you'll have to clearly mark it because an electrician might see it, mistake it for copper and allow it to carry a current higher than its rated for.

>The biggest issue with Al is that the surface oxidizes faster than you can work it so joining wires is a much bigger fuck around
Not quite. The oxides of aluminum are less conductive (more resistance, more heat at the connection) than pure aluminum. That is not the case with copper.

At high frequencies, yes. That's why the steel in copper clad steel in RG-6 cable doesn't matter for the signal.

>Let's see what happens.
So after 3 days in a warm place it was still very sour, but the acidity definitely got less offensive/sharp. I let it sit for 3 more days but I didn't leave a sample to compare to so couldn't really tell how it's going anymore. But the overall taste turned out rather meh, like there's something missing. With some sugar added I actually liked the original more, even though it almost gives you a chemical burn in the mouth haha.
Treating it with pectic enzyme helped removing most of the haze but it's still not perfectly clear.
In the meanwhile I also made another batch using different (clarified) juice with zero pectin and way less perceived acidity. The recipe was pretty much the same, there was absolutely no foaming, ended up with FG of 1.006 after 5 days. I didn't wait for bubbling to come to a complete stop, but the jar weight pretty much stabilized so there was little point waiting further. With some bentonite it cleared right away, and the taste is oh so much better, specifically there's very little acidity.
Interesting that unless I did something horribly wrong while measuring it, the two batches have TA pretty close at 5.2 and 4.8 g/L respectively, which I believe is pretty tame. pH is around 3.6 in both cases. So I'm pretty confused why do they taste so different.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531384
Not him, my experience says 5 weeks to remove the worst volatile alcohols and make it drinkable, 3 months to really mature it (for almost everything). I drink like half of my stuff at 5 weeks and keep the rest indefinitely (until Christmas or birthday or whatever).

But it’s also (probably more) important to keep it in primary for long enough so that the yeasts will eat most of the less volatile heavy alcohols. Once it stops fermenting, give it 5-7 more days before going to secondary.

Letting it ferment dry helps a lot with clearing (low gravity drops the solids more easily) and you can backsweeten it after. Filtering is kind of difficult using a home set up (without sterile pumps and plate filters etc) and almost never really necessary imo

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2531375
You should get the fruit out after 1 to 1.5 weeks, raspberries can start to decay under absence of oxygen which creates sulfuric compounds which in turn spoils your wine. Just strain it while racking it into a second fermenter. Press the pulp, because the largest amount of your yeast will sit in there and you don't want to lose them. After that, you can only wait until fermentation is done.
Testing for sweetness while fermentation is still going will result in you throwing out your entire batch, because it will only taste of yeast and sourness. (Which is completely normal but might give the wrong impression to someone new to this hobby)
Let it ferment completely dry, until no airlock activity is visible, rack it and let it sit for 2 weeks to let it clear. Then you'll get the first impression of where the flavor of your wine is heading.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2531406
EC1118 should go to 18% but don't be fooled by the SG of 1.020, honey has some unfermentable sugars, it's really rare to get honey to ferment completely dry, even though you should end up around 1.008 at least. Are you really sure that fermentation is completely done?
Normally you should measure the SG, take note and measure again one week later to see if the gravity dropped further.

Also you have your terminology wrong.
OG (Original Gravity) is your starting point. FG (Final Gravity) is the value you end your fermentation with and with which you bottle your wine. SG (Specific Gravity) is just the "unit" of the gravity.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2533531
>tastes like crap
Blueberry and cherry is a really difficult combo, I can't really imagine those two working together properly.

I think most people don't really understand that fermentation fundamentally changes the taste of what you put into your fermentation vessel. Cherry wine will never taste like cherry juice and the wine will always taste shallower, that's in the nature of it and the exact reason why so many combine it with mead to give it a proper background or foundation.
Also, I can't stress it enough, buy yourself an acidity testing kit. I bet my arse that your acidity is nowhere near where it should be to allow the flavors to come to shine. For a simple fruit wine without any fancy extras I'd at least go for a 7.5g/l.
And in the end it will help to just let it rest for at least 2 months, it will taste like a whole different drink. But with your combo that's not as easy as it looks. Blueberry wines love aging, after a year they will develop a lovely complexity but you can't do that with cherries. Cherry wine will finish developing after 1-2 months and it won't get better than what you have at that time. After a year the flavor and aroma will start to decay and the cherry wine will slowly start to taste bland and hollow.

https://www.thehomebrewforum.co.uk/threads/how-to-make-turbo-cider.69059/

Turbo cider is very quick and simple. Bear in mind you CAN make it taste nice, but like any cider within the first 6 months it's likely to be pretty shit

tl;dr:
>get apple juice (ideally pressed apple juice but you can use juice from concentrate too)
>get yeast (in theory anything but in practice best to get a cider yeast or some kind of champagne/beer yeast)
>make a strong cup of black tea (to replace the tannin you'd get from the apple skins in normal cider)
>put them all in demijohn with airlock
>some guys put in more sugar (to increase alcohol %) or yeast nutrient but I've never done either
>just leave it for like 2-3 weeks, it should start bubbling due to fermentation
>that's basically it

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2537858
>there are websites that tell me only do primary for maybe 7 days and then siphon
Those websites don't know what kind of brew you're making.
If you have solids in your brew like fruit pieces or pulp, you should rack after 1 - 1.5 weeks to split your brew from the fruit. You need to press the fruit / pulp, because most of your yeast will be contained in them. This step is not to get your brew off your yeast but the get the fruit out of your brew because they can start to decay under absence of oxygen which creates sulfuric components which in turn will spoil your brew.
If you have no solids in your brew, you should rack when airlock activity significantly drops, depending on brew, amount of sugar, type of yeast that can vary between 3 days and 5 weeks and can only be forecast with experience or if your recipe states the timing and your brew behaves like the recipe says.

>>2538571
I have a hard time to find English sources for all the German source material I have.
This is a very very short description of anaerobic decomposition:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decomposition#Anaerobic_vs_aerobic
If you click on the Anaerobic Decomposition Link in the text, you simply get to the article about Anaerobic Digestion and an explanation how it's used in the industry, which doesn't help us at all.
The German article is a bit longer, I'll post it here if you want to let your browser translate it for you:
>https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A4ulnis

The German article further states which components can be created via anaerobic decomposition:

Organic:
>Propionic Acid (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propionic_acid)
>Acetic Acid (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acetic_acid)
>Butyric Acid (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butyric_acid)
>Ethanol (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethanol)
>Various Amines (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amine)

Anorganic:
>Ammonia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonia)
>Hydrogen Sulfide (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen_sulfide)

Furthermore, there is always ethanol present in our brews, with which hydrogen sulfides react with to create Mercaptanes like Ethanethiol and other Thioles.
>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethanethiol
>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thiol

The problem with hydrogen sulfides is that it has a really steep threshold for human perception. Every brew contains hydrogen sulfides, it's a normal byproduct of fermentation and the human nose can't even smell it. But as soon as the threshold of 8-10 μg/L is reached, you'll immediately recognize it as a bad smell of rotten eggs.

Additionally I translated the text of this German Wikipedia Article using DeepL:
>https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%B6ckser

>Böckser (also called yeast Böxer or Böchser) is a wine defect. The wine gets (similar to the "corker") a so-called off-tone, so an unpleasant aroma. The smell can be reminiscent of garlic, onions, cooked cabbage or rottenness, especially rotten eggs ("H2S-Böckser"). Sometimes a goat-like odor is spoken of, which is why the name Böckser is derived from "buck".

>Böckser can develop as a result of improper production or incorrect storage and is more common in young wines. The "Böckser" is one of the reduction aromas that occur in the absence of air and is caused by the presence of sulfurous substances in the wine. These are formed by yeasts during fermentation, mainly from sulfur-containing amino acids and from sulfites and sulfates. Excessive sulfurization, residues of pesticides, a fermentation temperature that is too high or incorrect pH values can all contribute.

>In order to avoid the Böckser, it is advisable to remove the lees in good time. In the early stage, a Böckser can still be corrected by adding copper- or silver-containing salts (if necessary also together) to the must in small quantities. In use are:

>Copper citrate (in Austria only approved for large-scale trials)
>Copper sulfate
>Silver chloride (banned in Austria since 2001)

>However, as the young wine matures, the addition of these substances becomes less and less promising.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2538880
>i ordered some nutrient, is it too late to add?
Yes, nutrients only work in the first 3-4 days of main-fermentation. There has been talk here about a certain manufacturer claiming that their nutrients work wherever in the fermentation process, but I wasn't able to confirm that, since in my area that nutrient costs more than 10 times of the regional product that I regularly use.
Raisins give some nutrients to your brew, so there is no immediate worry. Does your brew smell strongly of sulfur, or just a bit? That might be a strong indicator of missing nutrients and/or missing oxygen (in the beginning of fermentation)
Which honey did you use? Orange blossom honey is notorious for a slow fermentation, depending on the region it might even get stuck and restart on it's own, really temperamental. Since they're your bees you should know which fields and forests your bees frequent.

And yes, you should take out the raisins, 2 weeks is plenty. After that, just be patient and let the brew do its thing.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2538927
>el cheapo grocery store juice
Check the label for the ingredients and make sure there is no sulfites in the juice.

Why would you think that a carbonated cider has remaining sugar? As long as there is sugar and as long as the alcohol tolerance of the yeast is not reached, the yeast will convert all sugars it finds. If you prime it and open it in the first 2-3 days, then of course you'll have remaining sugars, since the yeast isn't that fast but with each passing day the wine will get dryer until no sugar remains.

The thing with carbonation and sweetness is a strange one. CO2 in combination with H2O creates Carbonic Acid (H2CO3) which is acidic, so carbonated cider should taste less sweet than non-carbonated. But on my tongue, carbonated cider tastes sweeter than non-carbonated cider of the same acidity and sweetness. I don't know if that's a real thing or just some oddity of my tongue.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2539479
The plastic ones aren't able to be cleaned the same way that glass ones can and so they can sort of absorb weird flavors over time which carries over from batch to batch. When I'm using the word 'clean' here, I don't mean in the sense of sanitation but rather in the sense of chemical impregnation/absorbtion of the plastic.

The upside of them is that they're cheaper, lighter, and less delicate than the glass ones.

You will also find opinions from antiplazzers who feel that plastic will leach chemicals into your brew. If you wouldn't be afraid to drink water or a soda from a plastic bottle (or from a plastic lined can, in the case of canned beer and soda) then you'll be fine in terms of health risks.

>can you explain point for point where the article is wrong?
only in the praxis of meadmaking over the years, the JAOM recipe certainly isn't getting significantly more nitrogen from the orange. opponent.
raisins being dried grapes, grapes (and malt) have sufficient nutrients for fermentation to work. please note I say sufficient and not optimal. I happen to add nutrient with each pitch, but I'm also aware that millenia of boozemaking has made do with raisins.
I also happen to know that microbes are very industrious when they can't get their primary nutrition - eg malolactic O. Oenii eating citric when out of malic acid.
bottom line, brewers since prehistory and every prison wine vintner would conclude that the yeast are more capable of assimilating raisin nitrogen than a controlled lab test with a subset of s. cerevisiae would yield.
NOW.. I know this doesn't answer your point the way you wanted to, but raisins work albeit non-optimally. if you don't believe me, try the JAOM and see if you're getting fusels and sulfides.
The truth of brewing is that praxis trumps theory and if you told me that a Warhammer 40k chaos brewing spirit lived in my bucket I'd shrug and say "sure, whatever," and do what millenia of brewers have done.
I'd like to see the ceo of yeast nutrients weigh in though. again, big fan of pitching nutrient, but I bow to the collective experiences of drunkards everywhere.

>>2540327
it isn't great but brewing is very forgiving. the term you often see tossed about is sanitization, but not sterilization. this is because the real goal is to give the yeast a chance to out compete pathogens. yeast put out a lot of things that are toxic to bad germs (alcohol, co2, some acids). there are some non pathogenic bacteria that can give off flavors but even a lot of those can dwindle over time. the yeast are good at cleaning up and fighting off threats, you will likely be fine.
when in doubt trust your nose. if it smells putrid or strongly of acetone, stay away. if your nose says "eh, not great but drinkable," then it is just that. and if your nose says "yum" you are good 2 go.

For the time being, this is the only thing I found that clearly states how H2S is created by degrading biomass under absence of oxygen and it was directly before my eyes the whole time.

>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen_sulfide#Hydrogen_sulfide_in_the_natural_environment

>In the absence of oxygen, sulfur-reducing and sulfate-reducing bacteria derive energy from oxidizing hydrogen or organic molecules by reducing elemental sulfur or sulfate to hydrogen sulfide. Other bacteria liberate hydrogen sulfide from sulfur-containing amino acids; this gives rise to the odor of rotten eggs and contributes to the odor of flatulence.

Since all fruit contain sulfur components like Cysteine or Methionine, there is always enough sulfur for the yeasts and the remaining bacteria in the fruit to start the degrading process.

Page 65 and 66 of this book about creation of bio-gas describes a bit about the process, but again it's in German:

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2539990
>I'd like to see the ceo of yeast nutrients weigh in though

I absolutely agree with the aspect of "thousands of years of experience trump scientific analysis".
After all, to this day there is no scientific evidence that bananas help against diarrhea but still they do and thousands of nurses on this planet agree.
The thing is that nature and reality doesn't bend to scientific notation. It's the opposite, scientific notation is nothing more than a language that we use to make sense of perceived nature and reality.
Yeasts can thrive on thousands of different fruit, they live on the skin of thousands of different fruit and as soon as the skin is even just slightly damaged, the yeasts will take over the whole body of the fruit. Mankind knows this to be true with grapes for thousands of years. Raisins are nothing more than dried grapes, which can be hydrated just fine with most of their chemical compounds still intact. So why should raisins suddenly be of no use to yeasts?

This >>2540228 is just the perfect example, I've made hundreds of sugar washes in my life, even ones without yeast nutrients. Water and sugar, nothing more and still the yeast thrived. Yes, they weren't as efficient, yes the ABV was lower than normal BUT it created ethanols without a single trace of nutrients. Nobody on this planet can convince me that raisins can't be used as nutrients by yeast, especially under the aspect that "science" still isn't able to explain why yeasts have two different ways to convert sugar to ethanol and what makes yeasts decide which of the two ways to use.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2544993
The difference between brewing beer and brewing mead is that with beer brewing you need to create your "honey" beforehand.

You need to mash the malt, since there is no sugar in the grains, only starches and enzymes. By mashing it, you extract the starches and you activate the enzymes which in turn start to metabolize the starches into sugars. What is left is a water-sugar mixture like you have when mixing honey into water.

The easiest way to compare the two is by comparing mead brewing with malt-extract brewing, because they're basically the same. The malt-extract is like your honey, you mix it into your water and add the yeast. All grain beer brewing instead is all about mashing, because by your mashing process, you influence the properties of the "honey". (Metaphorically)

Technically beer brewing is a lot more cost intensive than mead brewing, since you need a lot of special equipment and an energy source like electricity or gas.

Just give a heads-up if you want a more in-depth explanation..

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2547549

>>2547565

Don't worry about the cyanide in the seeds, as long as the seeds are whole and un-crushed, the cyanide extraction is lower than when eating a whole apple with its seeds.
That's why I always recommend to freeze the fruit in the chest freezer over night and let them thaw the day after. That way they become soft and mushy and instead of crushing them, you can just squash them and they'll release a ton of juice.

To the blackberry and blueberry anon, be aware that fruit wine will never taste like the fruit or the juice before fermentation. Blackberry wine is the most extreme example, it will taste very nice and rich and complex, but it will have a sharp and almost peppery quality to it which might seem weird or offensive to someone who never had blackberry wine before. Blueberries go awesome with honey for a blueberry mead, the flavors go hand in hand.

I have no idea whether this thread is only dedicated to brewing or winemaking but I have started making my own liquors which we call in Poland "nalewka". It has nothing to do with fermentation, you just mix some ingredients with alcohol and the strong booze takes the flavours from the rest. If you have a good recipe then it will be delicious and cheap, if anyone was interested then have some recipes recipes and that's the first one:
cherry-chilli nalewka
1,5kg cherries, they can be frozen but the ripe ones in the season are the best
1,5l 95% alcohol
5 chilli peppers
1,5kg sugar
also you need a jar around 4,5l big
first you take the cherries and peppers and bury them in 700gr sugar and 0,5l of 95% alcohol
when the sugar melts (should take about 3 days) you add the rest of the booze
shake every other day, after a month filter it and pour it into bottles but not all of it, leave 1/4l of the fluid in the jar and add the rest of the sugar
after a week it all should melt, pour all the previously drained fluid into a big pot and add the second liquor (you can even squeeze the cherries now for you won't need them any longer and it's also 200ml more as far as I remember)
it should kick like a horse and still have a really strong taste, you can dilute it with vodka and have more of it, if you did it right then you should have a lot of 60% alcoholic liquor that doesn't taste as if it has alcohol in it at all, the chillis kill its taste, cheap and great
the cherries can be drilled or not, but if you use the ones with seeds then it has to be drained after a month because after 1,5 month it supposedly starts releasing toxins, if there are no seeds then you can basically close the jar and forget about it for a few years

>>2530888
From what I've read risk of infection when you reach active fermenting stage is quite low from air born bacteria. The reason being is your wort is producing enough co2 to positively pressure the vessel which does not allow anything in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2551314
It’s not really the positive pressure alone. Most bacteria found in people or their houses are either obligate anaerobic and don’t like oxygen (so they die in air) or obligate aerobic and won’t grow in your brew because there is almost no oxygen and a lot of CO2. Then there’s the high osmotic pressure, alcohol content, and byproducts that yeasts make specifically to keep bacteria out.

In the initial stage there is no alcohol, no CO2, and the yeasts are still pretty weak from rehydration, so there’s a much bigger contamination risk. But once the yeast is going there are few microorganisms that will be able to establish themselves in the must.

Lactic acid bacteria, acetobacter and brettanomyces (yeasts) are well known exceptions

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2551311
>extreme banana smell and bad taste

>Acetyl CoA + Isoamyl Alcohol = (Iso)amyl Acetate

Isoamyl Acetate is an ester which especially forms at too high fermentation temperatures and gives off a really strong fake banana smell. If your fermentation temperature was indeed too high, you might also have an higher than normal amount of methanol in your brew. In German Hefeweizen beer that ester is a feature and not a bug, but still it is created in strictly controlled amounts.

>Is the correct approach to take it off the lees and just keep it on a vessel for 2 months? Airlock or just close it?
Taking it off the lees and thereby filling it into another vessel is called racking and yes, that's the next step. Putting it into secondary fermentation for strictly 2 months is bullshit though, you should keep it in secondary as long as it takes to reach your desired final gravity, clarity or flavor. There is no rule of thumb. You should still use an airlock for every step of fermentation.

Leaving spent, cooked hops in the brew to ferment is not the same as dry-hopping.
Get that stuff out of the wort before filling it into the fermenter, it's just biomass that adds nothing but the risk of creating H2S.

Did you check if the gravity further dropped over time? Fermentation might still be ongoing, which means you racked too soon and you might still have active yeast in your brew. When you open the bottle, does it plopp and show signs of pressure?
There's two main reasons why a brew looks like that:
>Fermentation is still ongoing
>Fermentation is over and the dormant yeast was shaken up
Every other reason might be too niche for your case.

Hey Meadman, I'm making my first ever batch of mead this weekend. Can you shoot me some resources to make sure I nail it on my first batch?
Also, will homemade mead taste anything like the mead I buy at my local liquor store?

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2559762
I think the video from City Steading Brews does it best in terms of explaining it on a beginners level and keeping a proper pace for someone to follow who is not firm in the processes involved.

Take a peek and see for yourself if you can work with it:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y0W7K5yBK-g

How your mead will come out depends on several factors:

>Quality and taste of your honey
>Oxygen in your brew before pitching the yeast
>Yeast nutrients
>Fermentation temperature
>Yeast strain (Yes, bread yeast will work)
>Method of back-sweetening
>Acidity level

The biggest punch you'll get by backsweetening with honey, since fermentation changes the essential taste of whatever you fermented. This means fermented cherries won't taste like cherries, fermented blackberries won't taste like blackberries and of course fermented honey won't taste like honey. So by backsweetening with honey, you'll get some of that honey flavor back.
As for the acidity, for a beginners mead I'd just add a baking-sized packet of citric acid (25g) in a 10 liter batch, so probably half a packet in a gallon batch. You won't hit the optimum but even just a little acidity will boost the overall flavor of the mead.

Use a strong, characteristic honey, something delicate like Mimosa Honey will lose a lot of it's flavor and it takes a really strong process reliability to make proper mead out of it. If you're from the US, you can use orange blossom honey, if you're from central to northern Europe, you can try forest honey. If all else fails, just source a local honey and make sure that it has a strong, honey-typical taste and isn't too faint/delicate.

Beer yeast:

The strain/breed of yeast is the decisive factor of which kind of distinct flavor profile a brew will get, in the same way your cookies will differ in taste depending on whether you used Belgian chocolate chips or Swiss chocolate chips. First activity should start between 12 and 24 hours. But bringing water to a simmer for the yeast is too much, it's perfectly fine to use lukewarm water. Sudden temperature difference is what kills the yeast.
The reason your airlock goes backwards is that your brew was warmer than room temperature before you added the airlock and now the brew cooled down, thus reversing the heat expansion.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2562697
What exactly is your brew? Did you use honey, or fruit? Because they will add sugars as well.

I'm asking because your 330g of sugars, when fully attenuated, will yield a maximum ABV of 16.9. Also your picture shows something more like 0.981.

>Not sure if my calculation is correct but in the same way could 18% abv plus 95g/l sugar also be 0.985?
My rule of thumb (not accurate but accurate enough to spot mistakes) is:
3g/l of sugar = +1 gravity point
1% ABV = -1.35 gravity points (Thumb-rule only usable in a range of 4-12% ABV, the higher the ABV the more inaccurate it gets, above 12% it will get so inaccurate it's bullshit)

As your ABV will be above 12 but below 18, I'll change my rule of thumb to about -1.3 gravity points per 1% ABV and assume you hit around 16%

1.000 - (16 * 1.3) = 0.979
0.981 - 0.979 = 0.002
0.002 * 3g/l = 6g/l residual sugar

But now you realize the problem with formulas with 3 unknowns. Because now we can make the entire calculation again but with the assumption that you got 17% ABV in your brew...

I saved you the hassle and made a quick Calc sheet, pic related.

You see the original sugar quantity and the resulting OG, the Probable ABV is our assumption.
>Required Sugar = The amount of sugar to reach the Probable ABV
>Residual Sugar = The amount of sugar remaining after reaching the Probable ABV
>Ethanol Gravity = The gravity created by the ethanol of the Probable ABV
>Residual Sugar Gravity = The difference between the real 0.981 and the calculated Ethanol Gravity
>Residual Sugar = Residual Sugar Gravity multiplied by the factor 3g/l
>Delta Sugar = The difference between the two Residual Sugar values, the closer to 0, the more probable it is your real reached ABV

By using the chain of thumb-rules we can assume that your real reached ABV is around 16.5% and you have about 7g/l of sugar left in your brew, which is one hell of an attenuation.
But like one anon here once said:
>EC1118 will ferment a brick if it has enough sugars

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2563078
Brewersfriend is a website dedicated to brewing beer. When brewing beer, you will (with one or two exceptions) never ever see any final gravity lower than 1.005, thus you can't use their calculator for anything as highly attenuating as wine.

Furthermore, if you convert 330g/l of sugar 100% into ethanol, you'll get 134g/l of ethanol. Ethanol has a weight to volume factor of 1.2669 (1g = 1.2669ml), so with 134g/l you'll have 169.76ml/l which is just shy of 17% ABV. There is simply no physical way to get more ethanol out of x amount of sugar.
And since we have shown that with 16.9% ABV the final gravity should be lower, we can conclude that there is residual sugar in the brew, thus the total ABV needs to be lower than 16.9%.

As closing words I can say that all the calculations regarding water-sugar and water-ethanol mixtures change depending on the concentration in the water, thus you can't reliably calculate wine ABVs with beer ABV calculators. There is even historical evidence of people getting to know this fact with the German/Austrian wine-must gravity unit called "Klosterneuburger Mostwaage" (Also called "Klosterneuburger Zucker-Grade") in degrees KMW (°KMW).
1° of KMW is 1/17 of the mass-fraction of a water-sugar mixture of 20%.
The government of Lower Austria uses the following formula to calculate the ABV:

>((1.267 * (0.71173 * °KMW - 2.55)) / ((0.267 * (0.71173 * °KMW - 2.55)) + 100) * 100

The results for wine-typical ABVs between 11 and 13% are extremely precise, while below 11% ABV and above 13% ABV the whole KMW systems becomes hilariously inaccurate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2563107
>if you convert 330g/l of sugar 100% into ethanol, you'll get 134g/l of ethanol
how did you arrive at that number?

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2563125
>how did you arrive at that number?
By sheer retardation it seems, I can't even make up a way how I got to that number, it's absolutely absurd. I guess I made a typo when entering the data and carried that mistake with me till the end, I'm really sorry for that.

As a rule of thumb you always get about half as much ethanol as the sugar you used. (Reality is 51%)

Correct amount is:

>330g/l sugar = 168g/l ethanol

I corrected the beginning of my Calc sheet and all the new values cascaded down, pic related

Furthermore, here is how to get to the 0.51 ratio of sugar to ethanol:

>Molar Mass of Glucose: 180.16 gmol
>Molar Mass of Ethanol: 46.07 gmol

>C6H12O6 -> 2 C2H5OH + 2 CO2

>X = (2 * 46.07) / 180.16
>X = 92.14 / 180.16
>X = 0.5114

More concrete on the example of 330g sugar:

>330g * (1 mol [Glucose] / 180.16g) = 1.8317 moles of Glucose
>1.8317 mol * (2 mol [Ethanol] / 1 mol [Glucose]) = 3.6634 moles of Ethanol
>3.6634 mol * (46.07g / 1 mol [Ethanol]) = 168.77g of Ethanol

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2563328
As an addendum, the conversion from Sucrose to Ethanol is a bit more efficient:

>Molar Mass of Sucrose: 342.30 gmol
>Molar Mass of Ethanol: 46.07 gmol

>C12H22O11 -> 4 C2H5OH + 4 CO2

>X = (4 * 46.07) / 342.3
>X = 184.28 / 342.3
>X = 0.5384

More concrete on the example of 330g sugar:

>330g * (1 mol [Sucrose] / 342.3g) = 0.9641 moles of Sucrose
>0.9641 mol * (4 mol [Ethanol] / 1 mol [Sucrose]) = 3.8564 moles of Ethanol
>3.8564 mol * (46.07g / 1 mol [Ethanol]) = 177.66g of Ethanol

Since anon used an invert-sugar, the truth will lie somewhere between Glucose and Sucrose.

>C12H22O11 + H2O -> C6H12O6 [Fructose] + C6H12O6 [Glucose] (Same formula, different structural design)
>2 C6H12O6 -> 4 C2H5OH + 4 CO2

Here you can see that the yeast is utilizing the water from the brew to make up for the missing atoms, thus showing how the same amount of Ethanol can be created even though the molar mass of Sucrose is less than double the molar mass of Glucose/Fructose.
Also you can see a flaw in ACCURATELY calculating the ABV, since after fermentation is done, you have less water in your brew than when you started.

posts.com:
>>2562172
>the motor tag rates the triangle wiring for 220v/11.1amps and the star wiring for 380v/6.4 amps
380v*6.4a means it will draw up to 2400VA, which shouldn't trip a 500/15 breaker. Some anons posting using the transformer's ratings (380v/80a), suggesting that motor needs a whole commercial kitchen's worth of power are incorrect, that's simply the largest amount the transformer is capable of handling without itself breaking down. Unless its output leads are connected right to each other with very little load (impedance), it will never actually pull tens of thousands of VA.

The nature of this is odd, though, because that doesn't make sense with European power standards to me? Can any EU anons verify this, I thought you used 380v for three-phase supply. In that case I don't understand why a 380v-capable, async motor isn't wired directly to service without a transformer?? Is that transformer even triphase? It looks like maybe not? In which case I think it's possible the transformer is only there for your lamp, or another part of the machine that runs on low-voltage or from the USA.

The two black boxes DLS 10a above your x former (there should be three, actually?) look like motor starter current buffers, which act to prevent overload during certain mechanical conditions. This anon ( >>2562163 ) is correct, when a motor is held from spinning (or first starting up from a stop), it provides virtually no resistance and very little torque. Starters, which can also break down, contain a magnetic or electrostatic component that raises the voltage up as the motor energizes, rather than providing the full power right away when there's nothing to cap it to reasonable current.

You can check asynchronous motor coils a little with an AC meter though; connect your multimeter across one coil, put it in the highest-sensitivity (lowest voltage-range) AC mode, and spin the motor's spindle with a hand drill. It will act as a (tiny) generator if the coil is OK.

>>2562252
It’s an autotransformer, they are normally used to let the machine use different input voltages buy it’s hard to tell how it’s wired from the pictures.

Often they come with a switch that lets you select the input voltage you’re using, and they will blow fuses when on the wrong settings.

>>2562252
> The two black boxes DLS 10a above your x former (there should be three, actually?) look like motor starter current buffers
I would guess DLS here means Drehzahl Leistungs Steller, which can mean either soft starter or frequency drive, but could be mistaken. Btw the vertical axis says “Switchings per Hour”, the left diagonal line says “Reverse current braking” and the right one “Short circuit [something]”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2562321
>Btw the vertical axis says “Switchings per Hour”, the left diagonal line says “Reverse current braking” and the right one “Short circuit [something]”
thank you, I was having so much trouble trying to read that perfectly enough to feed into a machine translator.

Technically this part is named a "contactor" but it's really just a big relay. So I was wrong, they aren't motor starters, but simply part of the user switching circuit which turns the machine on/off.

It's possible one or more could be broken, in which case one or more of your phases might be either open or short. If you check the bottom of this nice page ( https://controlparts.com/pages/obsolete ) you will find that part, DLS 10a, with a nonretired replacement model that will be much easier to source.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2562415
Not that anon but no, they are three phase contactors/relays, very common in machinery. It’s just one coil that pulls 3 contacts at a time. Though on machines that have been used in professional shops it’s not uncommon to have a spare part already mounted (but not wired) inside the control box.

It’s also not uncommon to have an additional contactor in place, wired on the switching side, that can be used to connect an auxiliary device. That way the customer doesn’t have to change internal wiring to connect, for example, a desk lamp

>>2546079
youtube is like a company that owns a building in every town in the world. anyone can walk in and setup and office and start making content. after you've been there a while and have (maybe) made youtube some money, youtube will be like:
>we should start paying you (but don't fuck up)
>follow these rules that are vague and we can change them whenever we like.
>don't post video we don't like unless we decide not to care for X's channel.

so you upload videos and maybe get popular. some fall in to the trap of:
>I must keep one upping myself to keep viewers coming.
>posting videos 1 or more times a day.
>working more hours than they would ever work for a "normal" job.

then they have no plan B to fall back on when their channel eventually gets old or boring.

So my advice:
do content that you like
don't try to be popular
don't do it for the money
Have a plan B
Don't post more than one video a week.
Ignore advice (about your videos) from viewers that don't have a channel (with content).
NEVER make your hobby your job.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546079
>we should throw down some film

TV was sold as a groundbreaking educational tool, but with very few exceptions either didnt fulfill that potential or came with negatives that diluted its power and left it no better than traditional learning methods.

Hosts and their personalities and banter are one of those negatives, they exist to draw in viewers but that doesnt count as education and whilevit may entice fence sitters to get exposed to knowledge it can also drive away people who just want to learn. There may be an optimal balance but even then its a compromise that often doesnt *add* anything to the learning process.
Ultimately most "educational" video content is really either just entertainment or has been wrapped up in that format to make it more entertaining to keep the attention of people who otherwise wouldnt seek it out or are being forced to study the subject.
Theres a pschologically manipulative aspect of films and how they are edited and presented that people expect it and often feel that something is missing when a presentation is purely educational and to the point.
Theres lots of great tips and troubleshooting videos on YT but their usefulness is often in spite of being in a video format, and not appreciably better for it.
And for every one of those there's a dozen where all the other aspects of it being a "show", the personality and shilling for sponsors and editing for time and attention span and other obligatory showbiz crap make gleaning any actual information like pulling teeth and a massive waste of time.

Maybe we should discuss the investments needed to make your youtube channel viewable.

Follow the uxwbill model and film with an actual camera (old 480p and analog cameras have the cool retro factor, but good luck even finding them, and he moved on to hd later anyway) instead of your phone. I don't care if you have a $1500 flagship phone, it's video camera and microphones are going to be shit.
A handycam or competitor brand equivalent or a (used) dslr with an external mic is plenty, tripod preferable.
Either do voice in post, or do it real time if you can do it properly without uuuuuuuuuuuuuum ahhhhhhhh hmmmmmmm wasting time struggling to find words.

That's all I'm going to cover so far because I think it's sufficient. If you can film something with a real video camera, get what needs to be shown, and splice together the video, you're already a step ahead from any random retard monkey fucking around with a cell phone, and it's more than what most anons will try to do.

>Follow the uxwbill model and film with an actual camera (old 480p and analog cameras have the cool retro factor
anything lower quality than 1080 is out, it's shit. detail is needed for diy.
>A handycam or competitor brand equivalent or a (used) dslr with an external mic is plenty, tripod preferable.
I use a sony camcorder that shoots 1080p. I am avoiding 4k for now because it is very space hungry and extremely slow to edit and render unless you have a very fast computer with tons of memory.
>Either do voice in post, or do it real time if you can do it properly without uuuuuuuuuuuuuum ahhhhhhhh hmmmmmmm wasting time struggling to find words.
I use the built in mike on my sony 99% of the time if I am within 5 feet of the camera works perfectly.

I shoot top down video and since I have a tendency to uhh a lot when I am trying to be careful and accurate in what I say. I keep my hands out of the screen as much as possible and remove the uhhs. but leave them in if my hands are in frame. I even remove pauses in speaking. I despise rapid constant jump cuts in videos when someone is talking. If I am absolutely certain about something I am talking about or it is a subject I am very familiar with, there are no uhhs. if you bitch about it on my channel I will block you.

99.9% of my dialogue is unscripted and one take. I've tried scripted dialogue and it sounds robotic. The most I will do is a sheet of paper with talking points if certain things have to be mentioned.

I use a sony 1080p handicam for top down videos, a ring light all on a home made mount.

I shoot over a cutting mat. I often just clear a space by shoving stuff off screen.

sometimes I leave it, the people who watch my videos don't care.

some times I use old cell phones for multi angle shots. I use Magix Vegas pro 18 which (when it doesn't lock up) works really great. I just save constantly. it's somewhat easy to use and there are tons of tutorials on youtube for how to do fancy shit. I used to use Sony Vegas pro 10 (which also locked up a lot).

I have multiple tripods of various quality, and several cell phone holders for tripods.

I even wrote my own batch file to replace sony's awful PMB program for getting video off the camcorder.

>>2530328
The secret is that those wood pilings are submerged all the time. Without any oxygen able to get to the wood they last perfectly well for decades.
Other examples are the pilings houses stand on in the Netherlands or those supporting the Speicherstadt in Hamburg Germany.

For wood pilings it is vital that they're submerged all the time. The oxygen starvation prevents or heavily delays the decomposition processes.

Best example is now in the Netherlands those same wood pilings. Due to the heavy dewatering of the low laying areas for pasture the soil itself drops down exposing the pilings themselves at the top causing them to rot right under the brick walls.

There's an old dude on Ambergris Caye who's the last remaining fisherman in the area permitted to harvest live conch from the reefs. Every day he goes out and gets a haul of conch, then putters his boat over to the same spot where he's been cleaning them for decades. He pops them out of their shells, and tosses all the shells overboard, to the point that the spot is a shallow area from the tens of thousands of accumulated conch shells.
He makes middling money from selling the meat to restaurants, but the wild thing is that he could set up a 20 sqft stall in San Pedro and sell these shells to tourists for $50-100 apiece, easily. Could probably make 10x his current income, even accounting for the retail space rent and the cost of hiring someone to staff it full-time, but he just throws the things away. My mom traded him a cold soda for a shell the size of her head.

The only design I've ever liked was one built around a simple lever. The Splitting head was a giant heavy maul, probably a couple hundred pounds, on the end of a boom. On the other side of the lever there was a counterweight, heavy enough to just slightly overpower the maul and raise it up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2559717
Four options.

0: Use your PC sound card. You may have grounding issues.

1: Use a microcontroller and DAC to DDS it from a lookup table. Higher frequency output means pricier DAC and/or filter, but you should be able to get low THD without difficulty. I'd go for something like a pi pico or ESP32, and PCM1780. Maybe an Si5351 if you need a precise clock generator. Could also have two sines with arbitrarily offset phases, or custom waveforms.

2: Use a sine oscillator, with an AGC circuit of some sort to get a constant amplitude. You likely won't be able to get a wide range of frequencies easily, though with multiple ranges it might be possible. THD may be significant as a result of the AGC circuit. Both sine oscillators and AGCs are kinda funky.

3: Use a triangle oscillator with diode clipping. Pic related, it's the circuit from my analogue function generator, see U3/4/5. The diode clipping method isn't perfect, you get a slight spike at the peaks and troughs, but with proper tuning it's pretty hard to see. Adding further stages of diode clipping to shrink the spike even further would help, though I can't say for sure if the output wouldn't still be rich in harmonics. Some simulations might help.

Don't forget to add a square wave output to trigger your scope with, assuming it has a port for external triggering.

>>2559986
Does it run for a second again after you unplug it for a while and plug it in again? Might be some sort of stall/overcurrent or overtemperature detection in the trigger circuit. Might suggest carbon brush residue shorting out some comm-bars. I'd take the motor rotor out to check the state of wear of the commutators and to see if there's any gunge ingress. As the other guy says, the brushes are definitely something to check.

Does it hum at all when you're pulling the trigger and it isn't spinning? If you have a wall-plug power meter you could check if it's drawing current in that state, which would suggest a stall, maybe due to mechanical failure. Like damage or clogging in the motor, the bearings, or the gears.
